t: Job 28
Job Continues: Where Is Wisdom?
“Surely*pn there is a mine for silver, and*ld a place for gold that they refine.
Iron*ln is taken out of the earth, and*ld copper is smelted from the ore.
Man*ln puts an end to darkness and*ld searches out to the farthest limit the*ld ore in gloom and deep darkness.
He*ln opens shafts in a valley away from where anyone lives; they*ld are forgotten by travelers; they*ld hang in the air, far away from mankind; they swing to and fro.
As*ln for the earth, out of it comes bread, but*ld underneath it is turned up as by fire.
Its*ln stones are the place of sapphires, and*ld it has dust of gold.
“That*pn path no bird of prey knows, and*ld the falcon’s eye has not seen it.
The*ln proud beasts have not trodden it; the*ld lion has not passed over it.
“Man*pn puts his hand to the flinty rock and*ld overturns mountains by the roots.
He*ln cuts out channels in the rocks, and*ld his eye sees every precious thing.
He*ln dams up the streams so that they do not trickle, and*ld the thing that is hidden he brings out to light.
“But*pn where shall wisdom be found? And*ld where is the place of understanding?
Man*ln does not know its worth, and*ld it is not found in the land of the living.
The*ln deep says, ‘It is not in me,’ and*ld the sea says, ‘It is not with me.’
It*ln cannot be bought for gold, and*ld silver cannot be weighed as its price.
It*ln cannot be valued in the gold of Ophir, in*ld precious onyx or sapphire.
Gold*ln and glass cannot equal it, nor*ld can it be exchanged for jewels of fine gold.
No*ln mention shall be made of coral or of crystal; the*ld price of wisdom is above pearls.
The*ln topaz of Ethiopia cannot equal it, nor*ld can it be valued in pure gold.
“From*pn where, then, does wisdom come? And*ld where is the place of understanding?
It*ln is hidden from the eyes of all living and*ld concealed from the birds of the air.
Abaddon*ln and Death say, ‘We*ld have heard a rumor of it with our ears.’
“God*pn understands the way to it, and*ld he knows its place.
For*ln he looks to the ends of the earth and*ld sees everything under the heavens.
When*ln he gave to the wind its weight and*ld apportioned the waters by measure,
when*ln he made a decree for the rain and*ld a way for the lightning of the thunder,
then*ln he saw it and declared it; he*ld established it, and searched it out.
And*ln he said to man, ‘Behold,*ln the fear of the Lord, that is wisdom, and*ld to turn away from evil is understanding.’”
